critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.
critters.activeFact: White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food sources for years!
critters.activeFact: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food sources for years!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes are highly adaptable and can live in deserts, forests, mountains, and even cities!
critters.activeFact: Coyotes are highly adaptable and can live in deserts, forests, mountains, and even cities!

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm during cold weather.
critters.activeFact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm during cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes can climb trees, an unusual skill for members of the dog family!
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes can climb trees, an unusual skill for members of the dog family!

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, helping them catch prey and climb trees quickly!
critters.activeFact: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, helping them catch prey and climb trees quickly!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have thousands of sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.
critters.activeFact: Porcupines have thousands of sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams to create ponds, helping protect their homes from predators and harsh weather.
critters.activeFact: Beavers build dams to create ponds, helping protect their homes from predators and harsh weather.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, similar to beavers, but much smaller and cozier!
critters.activeFact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, similar to beavers, but much smaller and cozier!

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur, helping them stay dry and warm while swimming underwater for food!
critters.activeFact: Minks have waterproof fur, helping them stay dry and warm while swimming underwater for food!

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even chase prey up trees!
critters.activeFact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even chase prey up trees!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to eight minutes while hunting fish.
critters.activeFact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to eight minutes while hunting fish.

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst!
critters.activeFact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels defend territories year-round, storing food in scattered caches called middens.
critters.activeFact: American Red Squirrels defend territories year-round, storing food in scattered caches called middens.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows for storage.
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows for storage.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.
critters.activeFact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!
critters.activeFact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them identify objects by touch, even underwater!
critters.activeFact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them identify objects by touch, even underwater!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums play dead to avoid predators, slowing their heartbeat and breathing to appear lifeless.
critters.activeFact: Opossums play dead to avoid predators, slowing their heartbeat and breathing to appear lifeless.

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can accurately spray their smelly liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators!
critters.activeFact: Striped skunks can accurately spray their smelly liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators!

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide by spreading a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.
critters.activeFact: Flying squirrels glide by spreading a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats can eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes in an hour‚Äînature‚Äôs own nighttime pest control!
critters.activeFact: Little Brown Bats can eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes in an hour‚Äînature‚Äôs own nighttime pest control!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control mosquito populations naturally at night!
critters.activeFact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control mosquito populations naturally at night!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls can mimic the calls of other birds to confuse their prey or rivals.
critters.activeFact: Barred Owls can mimic the calls of other birds to confuse their prey or rivals.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow!
critters.activeFact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.
critters.activeFact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where both males and females sing beautifully.
critters.activeFact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where both males and females sing beautifully.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the winter.
critters.activeFact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the winter.

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use their strong feet to cling upside down while searching for insects on tree bark!
critters.activeFact: Tufted Titmice use their strong feet to cling upside down while searching for insects on tree bark!

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike many other birds!
critters.activeFact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike many other birds!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, about the size of a sparrow!
critters.activeFact: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, about the size of a sparrow!

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects, not just to communicate with other woodpeckers!
critters.activeFact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects, not just to communicate with other woodpeckers!

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers can drill holes 3 inches wide to find insects hiding deep in trees!
critters.activeFact: Pileated Woodpeckers can drill holes 3 inches wide to find insects hiding deep in trees!

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers have a strong, chisel-like beak to drill into tree bark for insects.
critters.activeFact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers have a strong, chisel-like beak to drill into tree bark for insects.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them surprisingly fast fliers!
critters.activeFact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them surprisingly fast fliers!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to duller feathers in winter!
critters.activeFact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to duller feathers in winter!

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos change feather colors seasonally, showing brighter plumage during breeding for attracting mates!
critters.activeFact: Dark-eyed Juncos change feather colors seasonally, showing brighter plumage during breeding for attracting mates!

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches have red feathers on their heads, which actually come from pigments in the foods they eat!
critters.activeFact: House Finches have red feathers on their heads, which actually come from pigments in the foods they eat!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodious songs that help them attract mates and mark their territory.
critters.activeFact: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodious songs that help them attract mates and mark their territory.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 miles per hour for short bursts!
critters.activeFact: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 miles per hour for short bursts!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating their wing feathers to attract mates and mark territory.
critters.activeFact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating their wing feathers to attract mates and mark territory.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform graceful, synchronized dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.
critters.activeFact: Sandhill Cranes perform graceful, synchronized dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if someone is a threat for years.
critters.activeFact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if someone is a threat for years.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech and animal calls, showing impressive intelligence.
critters.activeFact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech and animal calls, showing impressive intelligence.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their incredible eyesight!
critters.activeFact: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their incredible eyesight!

critters.name: Cooper‚Äôs Hawk
critters.fact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are skilled flyers that use surprise attacks to catch birds mid-air.
critters.activeFact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are skilled flyers that use surprise attacks to catch birds mid-air.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks can recognize and remember individual human faces for years.
critters.activeFact: Mallard ducks can recognize and remember individual human faces for years.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities, making them unique among North American waterfowl species.
critters.activeFact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities, making them unique among North American waterfowl species.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, often forming a distinctive V-shaped flying pattern.
critters.activeFact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, often forming a distinctive V-shaped flying pattern.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can fly at speeds up to 30 miles per hour while hunting for fish.
critters.activeFact: Great Blue Herons can fly at speeds up to 30 miles per hour while hunting for fish.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
critters.activeFact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than a second to catch prey!
critters.activeFact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than a second to catch prey!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill fish can hear sounds up to 1,600 Hz, helping them detect predators quickly underwater!
critters.activeFact: Bluegill fish can hear sounds up to 1,600 Hz, helping them detect predators quickly underwater!

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!
critters.activeFact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have vibrant yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater!
critters.activeFact: Yellow Perch have vibrant yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and use sharp teeth to catch their prey swiftly!
critters.activeFact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and use sharp teeth to catch their prey swiftly!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.
critters.activeFact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!
critters.activeFact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!
critters.activeFact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs get their name from their distinctive dark spots that look like a leopard‚Äôs coat.
critters.activeFact: Leopard frogs get their name from their distinctive dark spots that look like a leopard‚Äôs coat.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians in water, making them excellent swimmers!
critters.activeFact: Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians in water, making them excellent swimmers!

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to two hours while hunting or hiding from predators!
critters.activeFact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to two hours while hunting or hiding from predators!

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with similar coloring to avoid predators.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with similar coloring to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to Mexico each fall, one of nature‚Äôs greatest journeys!
critters.activeFact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to Mexico each fall, one of nature‚Äôs greatest journeys!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and avoid attacks.
critters.activeFact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and avoid attacks.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, left, and right!
critters.activeFact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, left, and right!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings back when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.
critters.activeFact: Damselflies fold their wings back when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, creating magical glowing light shows in warm summer nights!
critters.activeFact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, creating magical glowing light shows in warm summer nights!

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of tasty flowers with their hive friends!
critters.activeFact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of tasty flowers with their hive friends!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can fly despite their small wings by beating them about 200 times per second!
critters.activeFact: Bumblebees can fly despite their small wings by beating them about 200 times per second!

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that can leap over 20 times their body length in a single jump!
critters.activeFact: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that can leap over 20 times their body length in a single jump!
